member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_encodeSignal(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.UInt32,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Int32@,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Encodes the signal's value as defined in the corresponding Signal Encoding tables of LDF/SDF. If no SignalEncoding is specified for this signal, the value itself is written into destination buffer 'description'. If one of the required pointers is NULL or the buffer size is too small, the function returns the needed minimum buffer length in 'length'. It's possible to use two variants to get encoded signal: 1) pointer 'encUnit' and 'buffLen1' set to NULL: then encoded signal saved inclusive unit in buffer 'encSignal' 2) pointer 'encUnit' and 'buffLen1' != NULL: unit of signal saved separately in buffer 'encUnit'
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
Number (Index) of the signal accordng to SDF.
Value to be encoded
points to save location of encoded signal value (inclusive 'unit', if 'encUnit' not used)
length of 'encSignal' buffer
optional: points to save location of signal unit (if this pointer is NULL then 'unit' saved in 'encSignal' buffer also)
optional: length of 'encUnit' buffer (if this pointer is NULL then 'unit' saved in 'encSignal' buffer also)
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.summary: Sends the (textual) specified command to the BabyLIN device. Data response requested. The command must match the command syntax as specified in the BabyLIN documentation. The trailing ';' may be omitted; but you may not specify several commands at once! The content of '*length' will be set to really received number of data bytes. If one of the required pointers 'data' or 'length' is NULL or the buffer size is too small, the function returns the needed minimum buffer length in '*length' (if this pointer is valid).
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
String with the command (i.e. "status;")
Reference to data save location (destination buffer)
Destination buffer length.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_sendCommandFs(System.Int32,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Sends the (textual) specified command to the BabyLIN device with the ability to insert specific parameters. The command must match the command syntax as specified in the BabyLIN documentation. The trailing ';' may be omitted; but you may not specify several commands at once! This function works similiar to functions like 'printf'. You may specify placeholders, whose value get specified as parameter to the function.
Possible placeholders are:
%S insert signal number for name specified as parameter %F insert frame number for name specified as parameter %M insert macro number for name specified as parameter
Examples:
BL_sendCommandFs(handle, "setsig %S 1;", "signal name"); BL_sendCommandFs(handle, "disframe %F;", "frame name"); BL_sendCommandFs(handle, "macro_exec %M;", "macro name");
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
String with the command and placeholders (i.e. "setsig %S 1;").
Name of placeholders %S: signal name %F: frame name %M: macro name (LDF-Names)
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.summary: Sends the (raw!) command to the BabyLIN device. The command must be encoded in the binary DP-Message format of BabyLIN.
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
Buffer with the designated command(s)
length of buffer; gets set to actual sent command's length.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_getLastError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a C-string with the textual representation of the last error. The string returned is a pointer to an internal variable; don't ever try to free it! The errors are described in English. Note however, only Errorcodes < -1000 get described - all other return values are directly sent by the device. Values >0 usually denote the index of the wrong parameter of a command. Values < 0 define other errors like 'out of memory' and alike. Consult the BabyLIN documentation for further reference.
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
member.returns: C-String with textual description of last error.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_setDTLMode(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the Diagnostic Transport Layer mode.
There are different Diagnostic modes, which offer different levels of protocol functionality. The Baby-LIN will start with Diagnostic OFF on Power Up. If the BabyLIN acts as LIN master then the selection of an Diagnostic Mode happens trough the usage of the appropriate API function calls. So the API functions BL_sendRawMasterRequest or BL_sendRawSlaveResponse will start the Diagnostic RAW mode, where as the API calls BL_sendDTLRequest or BL_sendDTLResponse will start the Diagnostic DTL mode. If the BabyLIN acts as LIN slave then the DTL mode must be set by use of this function. It is not possible to use different Diagnostics modes at the same time !
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
DTL mode: 0 = DTL_NONE = no DTL Support 1 = DTL_RAW = RAW Mode DTL Support 2 = DTL_COOKED = Cooked Mode DTL Support
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_sendDTLRequest(System.Int32,System.Byte,System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sends the given DTL MasterReq to the node identified by 'nad'.
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
NAD of the node the request gets send to.
Length of the following data array.
DTL frame data (begins with SID, followed by up to 4095 data bytes).
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_sendRawSlaveResponse(System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends the given (non-DTL) SlaveResp upon receive of matching MasterReq with the specified as data (in as many frames as needed). Upon the reveive of the next MasterReq frame, the every bit of the requestis compared to 'reqdata' if the corresponding bit of 'reqmask' is set (1). If all match, Baby-LIN starts to send out the data given in 'data', 8 bytes with each SlaveResp frame.
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
Data of the expected MasterReq (exactly 8 bytes).
Mask for 'reqdata' to indicate which bits must match (exactly 8 bytes).
MasterReq frame data (multiple of 8 bytes).
Length of data to send.
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_sendRawMasterRequest(System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sends the given (non-DTL) MasterReq with the specified 8 bytes as data.
The internal raw-SlaveResponse-buffer is being reset and the Baby-LIN device gets instructed to report the next 'count' SlaveResp-frames which in turn are accumulated into the SlaveResponse-buffer which can be queried by BL_getRawSlaveResponse().
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
MasterReq frame data (exactly 8 bytes).
Number of expected SlaveResp frames.
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.LIN.Devices.BabyLin.BL_getRawSlaveResponse(System.Int32,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns the first 'count' bytes of the current SlaveResp-buffer.
The internal raw-SlaveResponse-buffer is filled continuously with the data bytes of reported SlaveResp-frames and is being reset upon every call of BL_sendRawMasterRequest().
member.param: Handle representing the connection; returned previously by BL_open().
Pointer to char array which gets filled (must hold min. 'length' bytes).
How many bytes should get returned.
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BL_getLastError().

member.name: T:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin
member.summary: The BabyLIN DLL provide functions to read / and write the BabyLIN

The BabyLIN DLL provide functions to read / and write the BabyLIN The following functions are used to get data which has been recieved from a BabyLIN-device. This apporach uses the pull method, i.e. you will not get any information pushed ( see callback_handling "Callback Handling" ) when it's received. Instead you have to call these functions whenever you want to get retrieved data.

\addtogroup return_values Return Values \brief List of possible return values of BabyLINDLL functions
The following values may be returned by BLC_ and BLC_ functions to indicate the success or failure of an operation. Mostly, the functions will return BLC_OK as an indicator for success. However, some functions use positive values to return the result of the function on success ( for example BLC_getFrameCount will return the number of frames )
Function successfully completed.

member.name: F:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_PC_SIDE_ERRORS
member.summary: Limit for separating BabyLIN- and PC-side errors; below there are all PC-side ones.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_open(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Open a connection to a BabyLIN USB-Serial device.
This function tries to open the designated port and to start communication with the device.
member.param: the port, the BabyLIN is connected to. It uses Windows-style numbering, which means it starts with '1' for the first serial port. '0' is reserved. On linux systems, the port is represented by the path to the device file ("/dev/ttyUSB0" f.ex.)
member.returns: Returns an handle for the BabyLIN-connection or NULL if the connection could not be established. You may fetch the corresponding (textual) error with BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_openNet(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Open a connection to a BabyLIN device using ethernet.
This function tries to open the designated ip and port and to start communication with the device.
member.param: the ip-address of the BabyLIN to connect to
the ip-port of the BabyLIN toconnected to
member.returns: Returns an handle for the BabyLIN-connection or NULL if the connection could not be established. you may fetch the corresponding (textual) error with BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_openUSB(System.String)
member.summary:
Open a connection to a BabyLIN USB device.
This function tries to open the designated port and to start communication with the device.
member.param: the usb device string, the BabyLIN is connected to.
member.returns: Returns an handle for the BabyLIN-connection or NULL if the connection could not be established. You may fetch the corresponding (textual) error with BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_openPort(de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_portInfo_t)
member.summary:
Open a connection to a BabyLIN device using BLC_PORTINFO information.
This function tries to open the BabyLIN device of the BLC_PORTINFO information, i.e. works as a wrapper for BLC_open and BLC_openNet which automatically decides which connection to establish.
latform independent way of connecting to BabyLIN-devices found by BLC_getBabyLinPorts or BLC_getBabyLinPortsTimout
member.param: the BLC_PORTINFO-structure of the BabyLIN to connect to ( see BLC_getBabyLinPorts )
member.returns: Returns an handle for the BabyLIN-connection or NULL if the connection could not be established. You may fetch the corresponding (textual) error with BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_close(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
Close connection to Device.
close an open connection, given by handle.
member.param: Handle representing the connection ( see BLC_open )
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation BLC_getLastError.

member.summary:
Close ALL connections to ALL Devices.
close all open connections all handles are invalidated
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_flush(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
Reset the BabyLIN device to an consistent and deactivated state.
Afterwards, the device will no longer monitor the bus, neither acting as slave nor as master.
member.param: Handle representing a channel; returned previously by BLC_getChannelHandle().
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_getChannelHandle(System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Retrieve a handle to the specified channel
This function returns a channel-handle for the specified channelId. A channel-handle is used to control a LIN- or CAN-BUS on the BabyLIN-device.
member.param: Handle representing the Device connection ( see BLC_open )
channelId Identifier for the channel to get the handle of. Ranges from 0 to the number of channels supported by the device (see BLC_getChannelCount)
member.returns: handle to the channel, 0 on error You may fetch the corresponding (textual) with BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_getNextFrameTimeout(System.IntPtr,de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_frame_t@,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Fetches the next frame on Channel from the receiver queue with wait-timeout.
Retrieves the next frame received from the BabyLIN. If no frame-data is available, the funktion will wait _up to_ timeout_ms milliseconds for new data before it returns with a BL_TIMEOUT returncode Important: The Device fills the receiver queue only if command "disframe" sent before.
member.param: Handle representing the channel to get the frame data from (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
Pointer to a pre-allocated BLC_frame_t structure.
timout to wait for new framedata
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.param: Handle representing the channel to get the frame data from (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
Pointer to a pre-allocated BLC_FRAME structure.
timout to wait for new framedata

Fetches the next signals for a specific signal from the receiver queue.
Important: The Baby-LIN fills the receiver queue only if command "dissignal" sent before. Important: This function will remove the signal values from the queue. Further signal receiving is no longer guaranteed to be in order.

Pointer to a pre-allocated BLC_SIGNAL (structure) array.
Size of the pre-allocated BLC_SIGNAL (structure) array, in units of BLC_SIGNAL, which must be a positive value.
the signal number to get the signals for
member.returns: number of signals found; '<0' on error. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_encodeSignal(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.UInt64,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary:
Encodes the signal's value as defined in the corresponding Signal Encoding tables of LDF/SDF.
If no SignalEncoding is specified for this signal, the value itself is written into destination buffer 'description'. If one of the required pointers is NULL or the buffer size is too small, the function returns the needed minimum buffer length in 'length'. It's possible to use two variants to get encoded signal: 1) pointer 'encUnit' and 'buffLen1' set to NULL: then encoded signal saved inclusive unit in buffer 'encSignal' 2) pointer 'encUnit' and 'buffLen1' != NULL: unit of signal saved separately in buffer 'encUnit'
member.param: Handle representing the channel to which the signal belongs (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
Number (Index) of the signal accordng to SDF.
Value to be encoded
points to save location of encoded signal value (inclusive 'unit', if 'encUnit' not used)
optional: points to save location of signal unit (if this pointer is NULL then 'unit' saved in 'encSignal' buffer also)
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.param: Handle representing the channel to which the frame belongs (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
frame number (according to SDF) to get the signal data from

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_setDTLMode(System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Set the Diagnostic Transport Layer mode.
There are different Diagnostic modes, which offer different levels of protocol functionality. The Baby-LIN will start with Diagnostic OFF on Power Up. If the BabyLIN acts as LIN master then the selection of an Diagnostic Mode happens trough the usage of the appropriate API function calls. So the API functions BL_sendRawMasterRequest or BL_sendRawSlaveResponse will start the Diagnostic RAW mode, where as the API calls BL_sendDTLRequest or BL_sendDTLResponse will start the Diagnostic DTL mode. If the BabyLIN acts as LIN slave then the DTL mode must be set by use of this function. It is not possible to use different Diagnostics modes at the same time !
List of DTL modes: | Mode | Name | Description | |-----:|:-----|:------------| |0 | DTL_NONE | no DTL Support | |1 | DTL_RAW | RAW Mode DTL Support | |2 | DTL_COOKED | Cooked Mode DTL Support |
member.param: Handle representing a LIN-channel (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
DTL mode: 0 = DTL_NONE = no DTL Support 1 = DTL_RAW = RAW Mode DTL Support 2 = DTL_COOKED = Cooked Mode DTL Support
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_sendDTLRequest(System.IntPtr,System.Byte,System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Send a DTL MasterReq to a node
member.param: Handle representing a LIN-channel (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
NAD of the node the request gets send to.
Length of the following data array.
DTL frame data (begins with SID, followed by up to 4095 data bytes).
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.summary: Send a DTL SlaveResp to a node
member.param: Handle representing a LIN-channel (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
NAD of the node the response gets send for.
Length of the following data array.
DTL frame data (begins with RSID, followed by up to 4095 data bytes).
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_sendRawSlaveResponse(System.IntPtr,System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary:
Send a (non-DTL) SlaveResp upon receive of matching MasterReq.
Upon the reveive of the next MasterReq frame, every bit of the request is compared to 'reqdata' if the corresponding bit of 'reqmask' is set (1). If all match, Baby-LIN starts to send out the data given in 'data', 8 bytes with each SlaveResp frame.
member.param: Handle representing a LIN-channel (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
Data of the expected MasterReq (exactly 8 bytes).
Mask for 'reqdata' to indicate which bits must match (exactly 8 bytes).
MasterReq frame data (multiple of 8 bytes).
Length of data to send.
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.name: M:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_sendRawMasterRequest(System.IntPtr,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary:
Send a (non-DTL) MasterReq with the specified 8 bytes as data.
The internal raw-SlaveResponse-buffer is being reset and the Baby-LIN device gets instructed to report the next 'count' SlaveResp-frames which in turn are accumulated into the SlaveResponse-buffer which can be queried by BL_getRawSlaveResponse().
member.param: Handle representing a LIN-channel (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
MasterReq frame data (exactly 8 bytes).
Number of expected SlaveResp frames.
member.returns: Status of operation; '=0' means successful, '!=0' otherwise. See standard return values for error, or for textual representation (for return values < -1000) BLC_getLastError.

member.summary:
Get type of a parameter of the last answer data from a BabyLIN
If the last answer to a command contained additional data, then this function reports the type and size for a specific answer data set. Data set selected by name. The following types of data sets are possible: BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_INT - 32bit integer, BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_STR - zero-terminated string (variable length), BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_BIN - binary data (variable length)
member.param: Handle representing the channel on which the answer data was received (see BLC_getChannelHandle )
char*-string with the name of answer data set
type of data set is returned within: BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_INT - 32bit integer, BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_STR - zero-terminated string (variable length), BLC_ANSWER_TYPE_BIN - binary data (variable length)

member.name: F:de.lipowsky.BLC.BabyLin.BLC_error_t.type
member.summary:
Error type
| Value | Name | Description | Status | |------:|:-----|:------------|:-------| |1|ERRTYPE_ID|Parity error in ID| | |2|ERRTYPE_DATA|Read data from BUS does not match send data| Frame-ID | |3|ERRTYPE_FRAMING|Framing error in data reception|Frame-ID| |4|ERRTYPE_CHECKSUM|Checksum failed|Frame-ID| |5|ERRTYPE_DATATO|Data timed out (incomplete msg reception)|Frame-ID| |6|ERRTYPE_SEQ|Unexpected state sequencing|internal status| |8|ERRTYPE_MACRO|Error in macro execution|internal status| |9|ERRTYPE_BUSBUSY|Bus is already used|internal status| |10|ERRTYPE_BUSOFF|Bus is offline (no bus power) |internal status| |11|ERRTYPE_BUSSPEED_DIFFERS|Actual bus-speed differs from LDF bus speed (Warning) |actual speed| |12|ERRTYPE_KWP_ERROR|Error in KWP|KWP error code| |13|ERRTYPE_APPLICATION|Application error|unused| |14|ERRTYPE_RESP_LOST|Response send buffer overflow occured|unused| |15|ERRTYPE_CAN_NOERR|CAN error disappeared|unused| |16|ERRTYPE_CAN|CAN error| bitmap 0x01 noAck 
 bitmap 0x02 stuffing error 
 bitmap 0x04 framing error 
 bitmap 0x08 recessive bit error 
 bitmap 0x10 dominant bit error 
 bitmap 0x20 checksum error| |65535|ERRTYPE_DLL_ERROR|Error in DLL occurred|dll status code|
